title: Soil Testing and Preparation
description: Test your soil pH before planting. Most crops in Kenya thrive in slightly acidic to neutral soil (pH 6.0-7.0). Add lime to raise pH or organic matter to lower it naturally.

title: Water Conservation Techniques
description: Use mulching to retain soil moisture and reduce evaporation. Apply organic mulch like dried grass, leaves, or crop residues around plants to conserve water during dry seasons.

title: Integrated Pest Management
description: Combine biological, cultural, and chemical pest control methods. Use beneficial insects, crop rotation, intercropping, and targeted pesticide application only when necessary.

title: Crop Rotation for Soil Health
description: Rotate legumes (beans, peas) with cereals (maize, wheat) to naturally fix nitrogen in soil. Follow heavy feeders with light feeders to maintain soil fertility.

title: Composting for Nutrient Management
description: Create compost from kitchen scraps, farm waste, and green materials. This improves soil structure, provides slow-release nutrients, and enhances water retention.

title: Optimal Planting Times
description: Plant at the beginning of rainy seasons for rain-fed agriculture. For maize in Kenya, plant in March-May for long rains and October-December for short rains.

title: Drip Irrigation Setup
description: Install simple drip irrigation using plastic bottles or pipes with holes. This saves water and delivers it directly to plant roots, reducing disease and weeds.

title: Intercropping Benefits
description: Plant complementary crops together like maize with beans. Beans fix nitrogen for maize while maize provides support for climbing beans, maximizing land use.

title: Post-Harvest Handling
description: Harvest early morning when temperatures are cool. Handle produce gently, clean thoroughly, and store in cool, dry places to maintain quality and extend shelf life.

title: Seed Selection and Storage
description: Select seeds from healthy, productive plants. Dry seeds properly (12-14% moisture) and store in airtight containers with wood ash or diatomaceous earth to prevent pests.

title: Natural Pesticide Preparation
description: Make natural pesticides using neem leaves, garlic, hot peppers, and soap. Blend, strain, and spray on affected plants during cool hours to control pests organically.

title: Greenhouse Farming Benefits
description: Use simple greenhouses or tunnels to extend growing seasons, protect crops from extreme weather, and increase yields per square meter, especially for high-value crops.

title: Market Timing and Planning
description: Research market prices and demand before planting. Stagger planting dates to ensure continuous harvest and avoid market gluts that reduce prices.

title: Weather Monitoring
description: Use local weather forecasts and traditional indicators to plan farming activities. Monitor rainfall patterns, temperature changes, and seasonal variations for better planning.

title: Livestock Integration
description: Integrate small livestock (chickens, goats) with crop production. Animals provide manure for crops while crop residues feed animals, creating a sustainable farming system.

title: Erosion Control Methods
description: Use contour farming, terracing, and grass strips to prevent soil erosion on slopes. Plant cover crops during off-seasons to protect soil and add organic matter.

title: Record Keeping for Farmers
description: Keep detailed records of planting dates, inputs used, costs, yields, and sales. This helps track profitability and improve decision-making for future seasons.

title: Value Addition Opportunities
description: Process farm produce into higher-value products like dried fruits, flour, or pickles. This increases income and reduces post-harvest losses during peak seasons.

title: Community Farming Groups
description: Join or form farmer groups to share knowledge, bulk purchase inputs, access credit, and collectively market produce for better prices and reduced costs.

title: Climate-Smart Agriculture
description: Adopt practices that increase productivity while adapting to climate change. Use drought-resistant varieties, efficient irrigation, and carbon-sequestering techniques.
